div.head: ¬ß 4. How to hold or place the Viol.

div.head: ¬ß 5. How to hold and move the Bow.

div.head: ¬ß 7. How the Viol is Tuned, and applyed to the Scale of Mu≈øick.
div.p: WE now ≈øuppo≈øe you to under≈øtand Song, and con≈øequently the Scale of Mu≈øick; which known, the Tuning of your Viol appears in ≈øuch order as you ≈øee the ≈øix Semibreves which ≈øtand one over another, in the fir≈øt part of the following Scale: where note, that all the degrees ari≈øing above the highe≈øt of tho≈øe Semibreves, are expre≈øs'd on the Treble or highe≈øt String, by ≈øtopping it ≈øtill lower and lower towards the Bridge.

div.head: ¬ß 8. How the ≈øame Notes may be play'd upon different Strings.

YOU mu≈øt know that ≈øometimes Notes are play'd, not on tho≈øe Strings to which they ≈øeem properly to belong; but for ea≈øe or better order of Fingering, are play'd upon ≈øome other String: An In≈øtance whereof you have in tho≈øe two Notes marked with little Stars over their Figures; which Notes, are play'd upon the ≈øecond String; though, a little before, Notes

div.head: ¬ß 9. A Rule for Holding on the Fingers.
div.p:

div.head: ¬ß 10. A Rule for the Motion of the Bow.
div.p: WHen you ≈øee an even Number of Quavers or Semiquavers, as 2, 4, 6, 8. You mu≈øt begin with your Bow forward; yea, though the Bow were imployed forward in the next Note before them. div.head: ¬ß 11. Of ordering the fingers in gradual Notes.
div.p:

div.head: ¬ß 12. The Motion of the Right Arm and Wri≈øt.
div.p:
I Told you before that you mu≈øt ≈øtretch out your Arm ≈øtreight, in which po≈øture (playing long Notes) you will nece≈ø≈øarily move your ≈øhoulder Joint; but if you ≈øtir that Joint in quick Notes, it will cau≈øe the whole body to ≈øhake; which (by all means) mu≈øt be avoyded; as al≈øo any other indecent Ge≈øture. Quick Notes therefore mu≈øt be expre≈øs'd by moving ≈øome Joint nearer the Hand; which is generally agreed upon to be the Wri≈øt. The que≈øtion then ari≈øing is about the menage of the Elbow-Joint; concerning which there are two different opinions. Some will have it kept ≈øtiff; In≈øomuch, that I have heard a judicious Violi≈øt po≈øitively affirm, that if a Scholar can but attain to the playing of Quavers with his Wri≈øt, keeping his Arm ≈øtreight and ≈øtiff in the Elbow-Joint, he hath got the ma≈øtery of the Bow-Hand. I can al≈øo admit the Stiffne≈øs of the Elbow, in Smooth and Swift Divi≈øion; for which it is mo≈øt properly apt; But Cro≈øs and Skipping Divi≈øion cannot (I think) be ≈øo well expre≈øs'd without ≈øome con≈øent or yeilding of the Elbow-Joint unto the motion of the Wri≈øt. div.head: ¬ß 13. How to order the Bow in double Stops.

div.head: ¬ß 14. Of Tripla's.
div.p: SOmetimes the Grounds them≈øelves are Tripla-time, con≈øi≈øting (u≈øually) of three Semibreves, or three Minims, or three Crotchets to a Mea≈øure. div.head: ¬ß 15. Concerning the Gracing of Notes.
div.p: GRacing of Notes is performed two wayes, viz. by the Bow, and by the Fingers. By the Bow, as when we play Loud or Soft, according to our fancy, or the humour of the Mu≈øick. Again, this Loud or Soft is ≈øometime expre≈øs'd in one and the ≈øame Note, as when we make it Soft at the beginning, and then (as it were) ≈øwell or grow louder towards the middle or ending. Some al≈øo affect a Shake or Tremble with the Bow, like the Shaking-Stop of an Organ, but the frequent u≈øe thereof is not (in my opinion) much commendable. To the≈øe may be added that of Playing two, three, four, or more Notes with one motion of the Bow, which would not have that Grace or Ornament if they were play'd ≈øeverally.

Graces performed with the Fingers are of two ≈øorts, viz. Smooth and Shaked. Smooth is, when in ri≈øing or falling a Tone or Semitone, we draw (as it were) the Sound from one Note to another, in imitation of the Voyce; and is expre≈ø≈øed by ≈øetting down or taking off the Finger a little after the touch of the Bow. In a≈øcending it makes that Grace which we call a Plain-Beat, or Ri≈øe; in de≈øcending, that called a Back-fall.

Sometimes a Note is Graced by ≈øliding up to it from a Third below, called an Elevation, now ≈øomething ob≈øolete. Sometimes from the Third above, which we call a Double Back-fall. This Sliding a Third, is performed commonly upon one String.

Again, a Note is ≈øometimes Graced by joyning part of its Sound to the Note following, like a Prick-crotchet who≈øe following Quaver is placed with the en≈øuing Note, but play'd with the ≈øame Bow of his Prick-crochet; This we have called a Cadent.
There is yet another Plain or Smooth Grace called an Acute or Springer, which concludes the Sound of a Note more acute, by clapping down another Finger ju≈øt at the expiring of it.

div.head: ¬ß 16. Shaked Graces.
div.p: SHaked Graces we call tho≈øe that are performed by a Shake or Tremble of a Finger, of which there are two ≈øorts, viz. Clo≈øe and Open: Clo≈øe-≈øhake is that when we ≈øhake the Finger as clo≈øe and near the ≈øounding Note as po≈ø≈øible may be, touching the String with the Shaking finger ≈øo ≈øoftly and nicely that it make no variation of Tone. This may be u≈øed where no other Grace is concerned. Open-≈øhake, is when a finger is ≈øhaked in that di≈øtance from whence it was removed, or where it is to be ≈øet down; ≈øuppo≈øing the di≈øtance exceed not the widene≈øs of two Frets, for wider than that we never ≈øhake. Graces made with Open-≈øhakes are the≈øe; a Beat, a Back-fall, an Elevation, a Cadent, and a Double Relli≈øh. The Beat is the ≈øame in nature with the plain Beat, the difference only a ≈øhort ≈øhake of the finger before we fix it on the place de≈øigned. This, as al≈øo the plain Beat, is commonly made from the Half Note, or di≈øtance of one Fret. The ≈øhaked Back-fall is al≈øo the ≈øame in nature with the plain, the difference only a ≈øhake of the finger taken off, which mu≈øt be done in the ≈øame widene≈øs as it ≈øtood.
